Self-Hosting Behind a NAT

Learn how to set up and manage self-hosted solutions behind a NAT, with tips for cloud and Linux users

No one knows what it‚Äôs like to be a bad man, to be a sad man‚Ä¶ behind a NAT.

Said a famous song (more or less‚Ä¶)

You Might Be Behind a NAT Too

It‚Äôs been years since the time when you would get a static IPv4 address assigned to your home along with your internet access. An address that you could use to ping your home router from anywhere in the world. Now, you‚Äôre lucky if you‚Äôre even offered the option to pay an extra fee to get one. Sometimes, not even a business contract will give you that.

Now, most of the time, your home or small business router will only be reachable via an IPv6 address. In some cases, your ISP might be using something like DS-Lite, which puts you behind a NAT (Network Address Translation) protocol, making it very difficult for you to self-host anything at home.

But‚Ä¶ Why??

There are just not enough IPv4 addresses for all of us, and although IPv6 is the solution (and although it‚Äôs been around since 1998‚Ä¶), adoption is still slow. Chances are, if your server is only available under an IPv6 address, most people out there won‚Äôt be able to reach you. You still need an IPv4 address for people to find you on the internet in 2019. Sadly.

So, if you want to be able to self-host anything at home, you need some kind of workaround. A dynamic DNS is probably the most popular option (one that supports IPv6), but depending on your ISP‚Äôs setup, that might not work for you either. So, what other options do we have?

Wait a Minute, We Have the Cloud Now! Why Should I Bother with Self-Hosting?

True. I wouldn‚Äôt recommend self-hosting at home for anything other than experimenting with software for your personal use. I wouldn‚Äôt even self-host my personal website at home.

BUT there are just so many awesome things you can self-host for your personal use‚Ä¶ here are some examples:

  • You can have your own alternative to Dropbox or Google Drive. Just buy a cheap 8TB hard drive and forget about paying monthly fees for as much online storage as you want.
  • You can use mStream or Koel as an alternative to a music streaming service (Spotify, Deezer, Apple Music‚Ä¶). If you have an mp3 collection from the days when an iPod was a cool gadget, you might as well have been missing it! It‚Äôs time to give it a second chance.
  • The same idea applies to Netflix: Streama
  • Who wants to upload photos to Flickr when you have Lychee üòÑ
  • You can even set up your own Kubernetes cluster using Raspberry Pi‚Äôs. Hours of entertainment await you with that.

Okay, You‚Äôve Convinced Me, I‚Äôm Behind a NAT and I Want Your Magic Solution!

Now we‚Äôre talking! If you want to self-host stuff at home and you happen to be behind a NAT, and if for whatever reason a dynamic DNS doesn‚Äôt work for you, you can always SET UP A REVERSE PROXY ‚ö°Ô∏è‚ö°Ô∏è‚ö°Ô∏è‚õà.

The catch here is that you need access to a machine that is already reachable via an IPv4 address. If you‚Äôre reading this, you probably have one. If you don‚Äôt have one yet, you can get one for 3‚Ç¨ a month and use it not just as a portal for your self-hosted stuff, but for hosting anything that doesn‚Äôt require a lot of processing power (that‚Äôs where I host this blog and all my side project pages). Some other popular options are DigitalOcean or AWS EC2.

You also need a machine (or more!) that is always running at home, where you‚Äôll run the stuff that you want to self-host. An old laptop will do. You just install whatever Linux distro you like the best, and you‚Äôre good to go.

Take a look at mine; isn‚Äôt it beautiful?

A Raspberry Pi will do the trick too.

Set Up a Reverse Proxy

I‚Äôm assuming that you already have something on that laptop that you want to make available online via an IPv4 address. Something that you can visit locally, like http://localhost:8080 or similar.

You also have an online server that is reachable via an IPv4 address, like this: 216.58.213.196.

First, install NGINX on your server. Once you‚Äôre ready, you should be able to visit the default NGINX initial page at http://[YOURONLINEIP:80].

Now, you can establish an SSH tunnel between your laptop at home and your server. This tunnel will act as a reverse proxy, where your local port (8080 in the example) is mapped to another port on your server (e.g., port 17899). To set this up, use this command:

ssh -N -g -R 17899:localhost:8080 yourusername@[YOURONLINEIP]

While this tunnel is active, edit the NGINX configuration on your server with the following lines:

http {
  upstream backend-home {
    server 0.0.0.0:17899;
  }

  server {
    listen 80 default_server;
    listen [::]:80 default_server;
    server_name _;
    return 301 https://$host$request_uri;

    location / {
      proxy_set_header Host $host;
      proxy_set_header X-Real-IP $remote_addr;
      proxy_pass_request_headers on;
      proxy_pass http://backend-home;
    }
  }
}

Restart NGINX on your server:

sudo systemctl restart nginx

Now you should be able to visit http://[YOURONLINEIP:80] and see whatever you have on the localhost:8080 of your laptop at home. ISN‚ÄôT IT GREAT?!?

Some Considerations

If you want that connection to always be active, you‚Äôll need to follow a couple of extra steps. Otherwise, the tunnel will be closed after a while, and the magic will be gone.

To do that, you need to first configure SSH Key-Based Authentication to establish an SSH connection with the remote machine without a password. Here‚Äôs a very easy tutorial explaining how to do it.

Once you can connect from your laptop to the remote machine via SSH without entering a password, you need a service that keeps the connection alive.

A simple and reliable way is by defining a systemd service on your laptop. To do this, edit a new file called sshtunnel.service in /etc/systemd/system/:

sudo vim /etc/systemd/system/sshtunnel.service

And add the following contents:

[Unit]
Description=SSH Tunnel
After=network.target

[Service]
Restart=always
RestartSec=20
User=[YOURLAPTOPUSER]
ExecStart=/usr/bin/ssh -N -g -R 17899:localhost:8080 yourusername@[YOURONLINEIP]

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target

Then run the following commands:

sudo systemctl enable sshtunnel
sudo systemctl start sshtunnel

The first command tells your system to run the service on startup. The second one (start) will start the service immediately.

Note: There are alternatives to creating your custom SSH service (e.g., autossh), but a custom service has proven to be more stable on my machine. Feel free to use whatever configuration works best for you to keep the connection active.
